title-group.article-title: Orbital, ice-sheet, and possible solar forcing of Holocene lake-level fluctuations in west-central Europe: A comment on Bleicher

article-meta.aff: 1Faculté des Science et Tecniques, CNRS-UMR6249, France

author-notes.corresp: Michel Magny, Faculté des Science et Tecniques, CNRS-UMR6249 – Laboratoire Chrono-Environnement, UFR des Sciences et Techniques, 16 route de Gray, 25 030 Besançon, France. Email: michel.magny@univ-fcomte.fr

abstract.p: Bleicher (2013) discussed interpretations proposed by Magny (2004) that Holocene lake-level fluctuations in west-central Europe suggest possible solar forcing of climate. He pointed out that the method used by Magny (2004) is a variant of a cumulative probability function (CPF) and cannot prove solar forcing of central European lake-level changes. He concluded that only few episodes of lake-level changes are climatically driven and that non-climatic factors were dominating. While Bleicher’s paper offers a stimulating contribution to the general debate on CPFs, the present comment is based on an approach which, in contrast to CPFs, excludes any consideration of variations in the probabilities over the time intervals given by calibration of 14C dates, as well as any distinction between types of dates (radiocarbon versus tree ring). It produces a revised pattern of the mid-European high lake-level events for the whole Holocene, supporting the hypothesis proposed in Magny (2004). Comparisons with other regional and North Atlantic palaeoclimatic records suggest that, without excluding other forcing factors, the successive high lake-level events recognised in west-central Europe reflect a combination of three main forcing factors acting on millennial and centennial scales, i.e. orbitally driven changes in insolation, impacts of deglacial outbursts and, possibly, variations in solar activity. Finally, it is clear that further investigations are still needed in order to improve the chronological data set for mid-European lake-level fluctuations, with particular attention to better defining the beginning and end of events.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Over the last decade, an increasing use of cumulative probability functions (CPFs) may be observed as a tool to reconstruct past environmental histories from regional data bases including large numbers of radiocarbon dates. However, the use of this technique has also become a matter of debate and some papers have pointed to problems undermining the use of CPFs (e.g. Chiverell et al., 2011). Recently, a paper by Bleicher (2013) has examined interpretations by Magny (2004) that Holocene lake-level fluctuations in west-central Europe suggest possible solar forcing of climate. Bleicher’s paper points to two major issues concerning the method and the interpretation developed by Magny (2004) as follows.

According to Bleicher (2013), the method used by Magny ‘rests on the comparison of a score record of radiocarbon dates with the residual 14C curve. This score record is a variant of CPF. This method is not valid because the shape of the CPF is determined by the calibration curve’ as shown ‘by a set of null models’. In addition, Bleicher questions a high lake-level phase (phase 7) defined by Magny at around 4000 cal. BP. Moreover, he observes that, from his point of view, ‘score peaks of the high lake-level record start too early in comparison to the radiocarbon record, which makes it difficult to see the latter as the cause of the former’, and ‘that generally the fit between dendrochronologically dated events and the residual curve is not good’.

The second point in Bleicher’s paper questions the possible climatic significance of Holocene lake-level fluctuations in west-central Europe. According to Bleicher, ‘only few episodes of Holocene lake-level changes were climatically driven, while most of the time non-climatic factors were dominating’. Bleicher questions the representativeness of high-score values, which are ‘sometimes, as in the case around 8300–8000 cal. BP, caused by several dates from only one lake’. A comparison with only two data sets from Spurk et al. (2002, based on a tree-trunk river record) and from Nicolussi et al. (2005, based on subalpine treeline oscillations) assumed to be proxies for precipitation and temperature changes respectively, allows Bleicher to rule out any general climatic significance of Holocene lake-level fluctuations in west-central Europe. Referring to Chiverell et al. (2011), the author points to ‘the unclear chronological relation between the radiocarbon date and the event itself’ within the CPF technique, possibly resulting in ‘a multiplication of the events’.
The present comment deals successively with the two major issues raised in Bleicher’s paper.

sec.title: Do Holocene lake-level fluctuations in west-central Europe reflect possible solar forcing?
Material and methods
sec.p: As pointed out by Chiverell et al. (2011), ‘there is a need for robust approaches and the analysis of regional data bases without loss of geomorphic information and meaning’. Thus, some preliminary remarks appear to be necessary so as to better evaluate the material available in our data set.

The paper of Magny (2004) relies on the construction of two histograms from two distinct data sets of dates relative to high and low lake-level phases. The reconstruction of past changes in lake level is based on sedimentological analyses of cores taken in littoral zones of lakes, i.e. in the areas most sensitive to past changes in water-table. High lake-level phases are marked by the deposition of more minerogenic sediments and poor organic content. In contrast, the low lake-level phases correspond to a greater accumulation of organic deposits (gyttja, peat). In general, nearshore areas are characterised by environmental conditions favourable to an accumulation and, consequently, a dominance of more organic sediments.

It is also important to rule out any naïve interpretation of high versus low lake-level phases reconstructed from sedimentological analyses. As shown by high-resolution lake-level records (e.g. Magny et al., 2008) and best documented by often huge accumulations of deposits in archaeological sites (e.g. Winiger, 2008) (Figure 1), phases of high (low) lake level should not be considered as homogenous periods of permanent high (low) water-table, but rather as periods characterised by a higher frequency of high (low) water-table spells. This probably better reflects the decadal- to centennial-scale climatic variability behind these lake-level fluctuations.

caption.p: Photograph of a stratigraphic section from the archaeological site of Concise, Lake Neuchâtel (Winiger, 2008). In general, archaeological layers (Neolithic and early Bronze age) are marked by accumulations of organic deposits (dark-brown colour) while lacustrine sediments correspond to sand and carbonate lake-marl (grey/beige colour). Sedimentological analyses (Magny, 2008) have shown how prehistoric villages at Concise generally developed during phases of low lake level. Both anthropogenic and natural layers are comprised of multiple centimetric to decimetric layers which clearly suggests that major phases of low (high) lake level include multiple secondary lake-level fluctuations. Thus, phases of low (high) lake-level conditions may be defined by a higher frequency of spells with low (high) lake-level.

sec.p: As discussed by Magny (2004, 2006), the lower lake-level episodes seem to be better documented by the chronological data sets than the phases of higher lake levels. This difference directly reflects changes in the sedimentary and lithological processes outlined above. The nearshore areas favour the recording of low lake levels by an extension of peat and organic deposition in shallow water, providing an abundant source of datable material. In contrast, highstands correspond to the accumulation of more minerogenic sediment layers, which are better represented offshore at the interface between littoral mires and the lake basin (Figure 2) and which are less favourable for radiocarbon dating because of their poor organic content. This disparity is also reflected by the fact that early-Holocene deposits often have a deeper stratigraphic position in lake sediments than younger deposits and, consequently, are usually less easily observed during field work.

caption.p: Geomorphological conditions behind the recording (and the reconstruction) of lake-level fluctuations in the littoral zone of carbonate Jurassian and peri-Alpine lakes. Grey colour and ‘u’ mark organic deposits and carbonate lake-marl, respectively. It is worth noting that the zone close to the shore favoures the accumulation of organic deposits while high lake-level events are better recorded at the interface between littoral mires and the lake basin. As a result, for the reconstruction of past lake-level fluctuations, core 2 provides a more representative lake-level record than core 1

sec.p: Despite the more abundant chronological data set to document low lake-level episodes, the present comment is based only on a data set of high lake-level phases which offer a clearer picture of past Holocene palaeohydrological changes. On the one hand, the chronological data set of low lake-level phases includes 21 radiocarbon dates (most often produced by conventional 14C measurements) with a standard deviation equal to or more than 80 years (one even reaches 240 years!). This results in large calibration time windows, increasing age uncertainty and finally a less precise picture. On the other hand, even if less abundantly documented, the chronological data set for high lake-level phases is most often based on higher-quality AMS radiocarbon dates. In addition, as illustrated in Figure 2 and discussed above, observation of the high lake-level phases produces lake-level records that are probably more representative of past palaeohydrological variations.

For the present comment on Bleicher (2013), we have used nearly the same chronological data set of high lake-level phases (Table 1) as was used in Magny (2004). Nevertheless, following Magny (2006),this data set has been completed with some additional dates so as to better document phases around 11,000, 5600–5200, 4000, 3200 and 500–300 cal. BP.

caption.p: Radiocarbon and tree-ring dates of Holocene high lake-level events in west-central Europe.

fn.p: Notes: CH: Switzerland; F: France; NE: Neuchâtel; AMS: Accelerator Mass Spectrometry; Conv.: conventional; TR: tree-ring; TMR: terrestrial plant macro-remains; cal. Median: median age extrapolated from two closely and well-dated (tree-ring or radiocarbon) horizons in the same sediment sequence (see explanations in the text). Radiocarbon ages have been calibrated using IntCal 6.1.0 (Reimer et al., 2009).

sec.p: As an important additional preliminary remark, one should note here the fact that the successive lake-level fluctuations discussed below were first recognised and defined in previous studies on the basis of the analyses of sediment profiles from 26 lakes in the Jura Mountains (France/Switzerland), the Swiss Plateau, and the northern French Pre-Alps. Their chronology was initially established using a combination of (1) a regional well-radiocarbon-dated pollen stratigraphy (de Beaulieu et al., 1994), and (2) radiocarbon dates in addition to (3) tree-ring ages obtained from archaeological sites (Magny, 1992,1993b, 1998; Magny and Ruffaldi, 1995). Thus, far from a more or less artificial multiplication of events derived from a possibly abusive use of CPFs resulting from a computer study, the regional pattern of lake-level changes established for west-central Europe relies on fieldwork investigations and observations coupled with systematic sedimentological analyses. This led to the identification of major phases of high lake-level conditions around 11,000, 10,000–9000, 7500–7000, 6500, 5500–5000, 3500, 2700–2300, and 500–150 cal. BP (see, for instance, figures 5 and 6 in Magny, 1998). This Holocene series of events has also been replicated using sediment infillings from Lake Cerin (Magny et al., 2011). A noteworthy exception is the high lake-level episode around 4000 cal. BP that had not been clearly identified prior to the paper of Magny (2004). In the latter study, attention was paid to a conspicuous low score in the low lake-level histogram which suggested a possible rise event (episode 7). These striking features then stimulated a re-examination of available sedimentological diagrams as well as new fieldwork and radiocarbon dating, which have finally fully confirmed the existence of rise event 7 (Table 1; Magny, 2006; Magny et al., 2012a).

caption.p: Method to construct the histograms presented in the upper panel of Figure 4. The example represents episode 15 dated to 11,450–10,800 cal. BP (see text). Panel (a) shows the four dates available for this episode (see Lakes Lautrey, Gerzensee, Zürichsee, and Neuchâtel in Table 1), and their corresponding calibration time windows at 2 sigma, while panel (b) shows the histogram constructed from data of panel (a).

Upper panel. Distribution of radiocarbon and tree-ring dates obtained to date high lake-level episodes reconstructed from sedimentological analyses for the Jura Mountains (France/Switzerland), the Swiss Plateau and the French Pre-Alps. At the base of the upper panel, black rectangles mark Rapid Climate Change (RCC) events as defined by Mayewski et al. (2004), and grey ones mark the Preboreal oscillation (Björck et al., 1997), the 10.3 ka and the 9.2 ka events defined by Björck et al. (2001) and Fleitmann et al. (2008), respectively. Middle panel: Variations in the atmospheric residual 14C (Reimer et al., 2004). Lower panel: Frequency of Neolithic and Bronze Age tree-ring dated lake-shore villages in France and Switzerland (Magny, 1993c,2004).

Comparison of the Cerin lake-level record (Magny et al., 2011) with (1) the curves of the summer and winter insolation at 40°N (Berger and Loutre, 1991) and (2) a treeline record from the Austrian Alps (Nicolussi et al., 2005).

sec.p: Table 1 lists chronological data to date phases of high lake level in west-central Europe. Since the development of the AMS radiocarbon technique, much effort has been undertaken to obtain radiocarbon ages directly from sediment layers deposited during high lake-level phases and thus their chronology was improved. Table 1 contains 38 radiocarbon and 3 tree-ring dates. Two additional ages are inferred from comparisons with the GRIP oxygen-isotope record. It also includes 24 extrapolated ages (mentioned as ‘cal. median’ in Table 1) for rise events bracketed between two closely successive low lake-level phases reconstructed from the same sediment sequence and well dated by radiocarbon (10 ages) or tree rings (14 ages). In the case of tree-ring dates such as those provided by archaeological layers, these interpolated ages may be more precise than radiocarbon dates. Interpolated ages were calculated as the median between two tree-ring dates or, in the case of radiocarbon dates, between the medians of two calibration time-windows at 2 sigma levels. Radiocarbon ages have been calibrated using IntCal 6.1.0 (Reimer et al., 2009). All in all, this data set includes 67 ages.

According to the method illustrated in Figure 3, Figure 4 presents the distribution of the dates for rise events over the entire Holocene. As in Magny (2004, 2006), a time resolution of 50 years was chosen to construct the histogram. However, in contrast with Magny (2004), each time a 50 yr period was documented in a 2 sigma calibration time-window or by a tree-ring date, it was given 1 point regardless of its type, i.e. radiocarbon or tree ring. In addition, any distinction between 1 and 2 sigma calibration intervals was ignored. This simple robust method excludes any possible score modulation linked to varying probabilities within the time interval given by calibration and thus avoids any problem undermining the use of CPFs (Bleicher, 2013; Chiverell et al., 2011).

Before beginning with the presentation and discussion of results, it seems important to remind here, even if it appears to be a truism and despite uncertainties inherent in the radiocarbon dating, that a radiocarbon date mainly reflects the age of the dated event and its position in the Holocene, while the precision strongly depends on the position of the measured sample on the calibration curve.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the distribution of the chronological data (Table 1) relative to high lake-level phases over the entire Holocene using the method described above. The picture that emerges is close to that published by Magny (2004, 2006), while using a slightly different method, i.e. when it was given 2 or 1 point(s) to a 50 yr interval each time it was documented in a 1 or 2 sigma calibration time-window, and 3 points when documented by a tree-ring date (Magny, 2004). While Bleicher (2013) criticizes this method as being a variant of CPFs, the close similarities between the results presented here, based on a revised method, and those published by Magny (2004) suggest that the sediment record shows real events and is not just an artefact with fluctuations due to the troughs and peaks in the calibration curve.
Once again, 15 successive episodes of higher lake level may be defined as follows.

Episode 15 (11,350–11,100 cal. BP) is well documented and dated in Lakes Lautrey, Gerzensee, Zürichsee, Morat and Neuchâtel (Magny, 2001; Magny and Richoz, 2000; Magny et al., 2003c, 2006a). At Lakes Gerzensee and Lautrey, the age of this episode is also confirmed by a comparison with the GRIP oxygen-isotope record (Ammann et al., 2000), and at Lake Neuchâtel by the use of the wiggle matching technique (Magny et al., 2003c). The interval 11,350–11,100 cal. BP may also include forerunner events as observed at Lakes Gerzensee and Lautrey. This lake-level episode has also been recognised at Lakes Remoray, Onoz and Morat (Magny and Ruffaldi, 1995; Renssen et al., 2000) and it coincided with increasing runoff in the catchment area of Lake Saint-Point dated to 11,400–11,200 cal. BP (Magny et al., 2012c).

Episodes 14 (10,250–9900 cal. BP) and 13 (9550–9350 cal. BP): the first is documented and dated at Lakes Morat and Annecy, the second at Lakes Grand Lemps and Annecy (Clercet al., 1989; Magny et al., 2001b). The distinction between two successive events is clearly apparent in two sediment sequences from Lake Annecy (Magny, 2001; Magny et al., 2001b). This succession of events is supported by reconstructions for the former Lake Wallisellen on the Swiss Plateau (Haas et al., 1998) and for Lake Le Locle in the Jura Mountains (Magny et al., 2001a).

Episode 12 (8400–8050 cal. BP) is well documented and dated at Lake Annecy (Magny et al., 2003a, 2003b) where it is composed of two short-lived rise events. This episode is also documented at Lake Neuchâtel (Magny, 2008), Le Locle (Magnyet al., 2001a) and at Wallisellen where a similar succession of two rise events has been observed and dated to c. 8450 and 8200 cal. BP (Haas et al., 1998). It also corresponds to an increasing runoff (i.e. wetter climatic conditions) in the Lake Saint-Point catchment area dated to c. 8500–8400 cal. BP (Magny et al., 2012c).

Episode 11 (7700–7000 cal. BP) is the best-documented event with data from Lakes Cerin, Grand Lemps, Chalain, Neuchâtel, Morat and Bodensee (Clerc et al., 1989; Magny, 2008; Magny et al., 2006b, 2011; Richard, 1997, 2000). It is also documented at Lakes Le Locle (Magny et al., 2001a) and Seedorf (Magny and Richoz, 1998).

Episode 10 (6350/6100–5950/5900 cal. BP) is clearly comprised of two successive events as well, documented at Lakes Morat, Annecy, Remoray and Seedorf (Magny and Richoz, 1998; Magny and Ruffaldi, 1995; Magny et al., 2005a, 2005b). This phase has also been recognised at Lake Grand Maclu (Magny, 2004). At Lake Saint-Point, in addition to a rise in lake level (Magny and Ruffaldi, 1995), this event marks the starting point of an increase in runoff around 6200 cal. BP close to the transition between the Holocene climatic optimum and the Neoglacial (Magny et al., 2012c).

Episode 9 (5650–5200 cal. BP) has been well documented and dated from sediment sequences sampled in archaeological sites of Lakes Chalain, Clairvaux, Seedorf, Neuchâtel and Bodensee (Haas et al., 1998; Magny, 1992,2008; Magny and Richoz, 1998; Magny et al., 2006b). Like at Lake Cerin, the sediment sequence of Arbon, Lake Bodensee, gives evidence of three successive rise events which mimic the three 14C peaks between 5600 and 5200 cal. BP (Magny et al., 2006b, 2011).
Episode 8 (4850–4800 cal. BP). Well tree-ring dated, this abrupt short-lived rise in lake level has been recognised at Lakes Neuchâtel, Chalain and Clairvaux (Magny, 1992,2004,2008).

Episode 7 (4300–3750 cal. BP). First documented and radiocarbon-dated at Lake Petit Maclu (Magny, 2006), this episode has now been well established from the high-resolution record from Chatillon, Lake Bourget, where the sediment sequence gives evidence of a complex palaeohydrological oscillation dated by wiggle-matching to c. 4300–3850 cal. BP (Magny et al., 2012a). It was also recognised at Lakes Pluvis, Neuchâtel, Cerin and possibly at Lake Morat (Magny et al., 2005a, 2011, 2012a).

Episode 6 (3350–3100 cal. BP) has been documented and dated at Lakes Pluvis, Annecy and Bourget (Magny, 2004; Magny et al., 2007, 2009b, 2011). It is also well documented by sediment sequences of Lake Clairvaux (where it may have been initiated as early as 1650–1600 bc, i.e. 3600–3550 cal. BP; Magny, 1992) and Lake Cerin where it developed around 3320 cal. BP (Magny et al., 2011).

Episode 5 (2750–2300 cal. BP) has been documented and dated at Lakes Annecy (Magny, 2004) and Paladru (Borel et al., 1998). At Lake Bourget, the beginning of the rise event is dated by tree-ring data to c. 2764 cal. BP (Magny et al., 2012a). It has also been recognised at Lakes Cerin (Magny et al., 2011) and Seedorf, Bourget, and Clairvaux where a bipartite oscillation has been reconstructed (Magny, 2003; Magny and Richoz, 1998; Magny et al., 2009a).
Episode 4 (1800–1700 cal. BP) was first documented and dated at Lake Petit Maclu (Magny, 1992). It is also documented at Lakes Cerin, Morat and Neuchâtel (Magny et al., 2005a, 2011).

Episode 3 (1350–1200 cal. BP) has been documented and dated at Lake Abbaye (Magny, 2004). It has also been recognised at Lakes Morat and Neuchâtel (Magny et al., 2005a), and at Lake Paladru (Borel et al., 1998).

Episode 2 (750–650 cal. BP) has been documented and dated at Lakes Annecy (Magny et al., 2001b) and Paladru where it developed after the abandonment of a medieval lake-shore village tree-ring dated to c. ad 1040, i.e. 910 cal. BP (Borel et al., 1998; Brochier and Druart, 1993). It has also been observed at Lakes Joux and Saint-Point (Magny et al., 2008, 2010).

Episode 1 (500–300 cal. BP) has been well documented and dated at Lakes Joux and Saint Point (Magny et al., 2008, 2010). It has also been documented at Lakes Neuchâtel, Morat (Magnyet al., 2005a) and Ilay (Magny et al., 1995) where the rise event started just before ad 1394, i.e. 556 cal. BP).

Figure 4 shows a comparison of the west-central Europe lake-level record with the atmospheric residual 14C record (Reimeret al., 2004), which may be considered as a proxy record for past changes in solar activity. This is confirmed by similarities with the 10Be record, even if the 14C curve may – apart from production and dilution in the atmosphere – also reflect exchanges with carbon-dioxide reservoirs on Earth, i.e. the ocean and the biosphere (Beer, 2000; Finkel and Nishiizumi, 1997; Muscheler et al., 1999, 2000). All together, most of the 15 episodes of high lake level appear to coincide, at least partly, with peaks in the curve of the 14C (except from the event dated to 4300–3750 cal. BP which corresponds to generally low 14C values and will be discussed in the following section). Thus, this revised lake-level data set supports the interpretation proposed by Magny (2004, 2006) that, without excluding other possible factors, solar activity may have played an important role in Holocene climate changes (precipitation, temperature dependent evaporation) over the mid-European latitudes.

Bleicher (2013) mentions the fact that the first three peaks of high lake-level record start too early in comparison with the radiocarbon record. Such time lags may be easily explained if we take into account the age uncertainties inherent in the radiocarbon dating. It is also evident that the ages of episodes 14 and 13 need to be better documented by additional radiocarbon dates. Moreover, van der Plicht et al. (2004) have shown the possible complexity of the Preboreal climate reversal where two successive events may be distinguished, i.e. the first provoked by a deglacial meltwater pulse and the second one associated with a decrease in solar activity. Similarly, Magny and Bégeot (2004) have shown how the mid-European phases of higher lake levels between 11,700 and 7000 cal. BP may have resulted from a combination of forcing factors including variations in solar activity and successive freshwater outbursts from north-European and North American proglacial lakes. Finally, van Geel et al. (1999) have pointed out how the start of sharp rises in 14C coincided with evidence for abrupt cooling from palaeoclimatic records, instead it takes time to build up higher 14C values in the atmosphere when the solar activity decreases.

Bleicher (2013) argues ‘that generally the fit between dendrochronologically dated events and the residual curve is not good’. However, the Neolithic and Bronze Age lake-dwellings offer a nice opportunity to test the hypothesis of a possible influence of varying solar activity on lake-level changes for the period from c. 6000 to c. 2500 cal. BP. The lowest panel in Figure 4 shows the frequency of Neolithic and Bronze Age lake-dwellings using a data set of more than 150 tree-ring dates provided by wooden posts used by prehistoric people for dwelling constructions (Magny, 1993c; see also Figure 1). The quasi-disappearance of lake-shore villages during phases of higher lake-level conditions and sharply rising atmospheric 14C clearly suggest a general abandonment of prehistoric villages threatened by rising lake levels in response to climate change induced by decreasing solar activity. As noted above, the hypothesis of solar forcing does not appear to be relevant for episode 7 between 4300 and 3750 cal. BP (see the discussion below, in the following section). In any case, when considered as a whole, the variations in the frequency of tree-ring dated prehistoric lake-dwellings offer a precise tree-ring based control (though indirect) for the chronology of lake-level events presented in the upper panel in Figure 4 over the period 6000–2500 cal BP. Billamboz (2007) comes to similar observations for the successive periods of development and abandonment of protohistorical lake-dwellings in the south Germany, with a quasi-disappearance of villages in humid areas (lake shores and peatlands) during phases of higher values in atmospheric 14C around 3350–3150 and 2800–2700 cal. BP. Iron age lake-dwellings re-appeared as early as 2700 cal. BP when solar activity increased as shown by decreasing atmospheric 14C values.

To conclude this section about solar forcing, it is noteworthy that such a hypothesis of a possible solar influence on climate change in west-central Europe is fully supported by other studies based on various indicators such as palaeohydrological changes reconstructed from Lake Meerfelder Maar (Martin-Puertas et al., 2012), and Lake Ammersee in Germany (Czymzik, 2012), Lake Bourget in the French Pre-Alps (Magny et al., 2010), rivers of the Swiss Plateau (Schulte et al., 2009), treeline records in the Austrian Alps (Nicolussi et al., 2009), or oxygen-isotope records from speleothems in Austria (Mangini et al., 2005). Last but not least, on a larger scale, using (1) a lake-level data set from the North Atlantic area based on a compilation from the literature and (2) an approach based on a Principal Components Analysis, Shuman and Plank (2011) have shown how, after the deglaciation, variations in lake levels may have been driven by varying solar activity in Europe as well as in North America.

sec.title: Are Holocene lake-level fluctuations in west-central Europe driven by climatic change?
sec.p: The preceding section has at least in part responded to this question with similarities observed between lake-level changes on a regional scale (Harrison and Digerfeldt, 1993; Harrison et al., 1993), and possible correlations between regional high lake-level events and sharp increases of the 14C curve which suggest solar forcing. A second step to evaluate a possible influence of climate on lake-level fluctuations in west-central Europe is to compare the evidence with other palaeoclimatic records reconstructed in mid-European latitudes or in other regions. Thus, taking into account the radiocarbon dating uncertainty, previous papers (Magny, 1992,1998) in addition to that of Magny and Ruffaldi (1995) cited by Bleicher (2013), have suggested possible correlations between the mid-European lake-level record and glacier movements in the Austrian Alps (Bortenschlager, 1977; Patzelt, 1977), in the Swiss Alps (Zoller, 1977), and timberline variations in the Swiss Alps (Burga, 1988), as well as with variations in the Upper Vistula discharge (Starkel, 1991), an oxygen-isotope record from Greenland and treeline movements in northern America (Magny, 1993a). More recently, on a regional scale, possible coincidences have been pointed out between the west-central European lake-level record and variations in flood activity reconstructed from deep cores in Lake Bourget, in the French Pre-Alps, throughout the Holocene (Arnaud et al., 2012; Debret et al., 2010), as well as between glacier advances in the Swiss Alps and mid-European lake-level rise events over the last 3500 years (Holzhauser et al., 2005; Magny et al., 2010).

On a larger scale, the present study supports (1) the hypothesis of possible correlations between the west-central high lake-level record as presented in Figure 4 and North Atlantic Ice-Rafted Debris (Bond et al., 1997, 2001) and Greenland Polar Circulation Index (Mayewski et al., 1997) records as proposed in previous works (Magny 1999,2004,2006), and (2) that of possible teleconnections in a complex cryosphere–ocean–atmosphere system where solar forcing may have played an important role to modulate the Holocene climatic variability in the North Atlantic area (Magny, 2004,2006). Moreover, recent studies have shown how the mid-European lake-level record is a consistent piece of a more general palaeohydrological puzzle (1) in Europe during the Holocene, with a wet mid-European zone contrasting with drier zones in northern and southern Europe in response to centennial cooling phases (Magny et al., 2003b), and (2) in the North Atlantic area and the Mediterranean basin, with modulation by solar forcing and the Arctic/North Atlantic Oscillation (Lamy et al., 2006).

Keeping in mind uncertainties linked with the radiocarbon dating, Figure 4 points to possible correlations between the successive high lake-level events reconstructed for west-central Europe and series of centennial-scale events recognised in the North Atlantic area from other studies (Alley et al., 1997; Björck et al., 1997, 2001; Fleitmann et al., 2008; Mayewski et al., 2004; van der Plicht et al., 2004) as seen below.

Episode 15 (11,350–11,100 cal. BP) may be coeval, at least in part, with the Preboreal oscillation (PBO) dated to 11,300–11,150 cal. BP by Björck et al. (1997). Forerunner events observed at Lakes Lautrey and Gerzensee (Magny, 2001; Magny et al., 2006a) may correspond to the several successive short-lived oscillations reconstructed by Björck and Wastegård (1999) in middle Sweden during the first part of the Preboreal.

Episode 14 (10,250–9900 cal. BP) and episode 13 (9550–9350 cal. BP) are close to the cooling event defined by Björck et al. (2001) at 10,300 cal. BP from various records in the Northern Hemisphere, as well as close to the widespread event described by Fleitmann et al. (2008) around 9300–9200 cal. BP in response to deglacial outbursts. Together, these two ‘Boreal oscillations’ (Brathauer et al., 2000) may find equivalents in many ice, marine and continental records in the North Atlantic area as listed by Magny et al. (2001b).

Episode 12 (8400–8050 cal. BP) corresponds to the 8.2 ka event, which marks the early- to mid-Holocene transition (Alley et al., 1997; Walker et al., 2012). Rohling and Palike (2005) have shown how this event may be a part of a possibly longer climatic oscillation between 8500 and 8000 cal. BP. The quantitative reconstruction of climatic parameters for this cooling event in west-central Europe (Magny et al., 2003b) is consistent with the glacier advance recognised by Nicolussi and Schlüchter (2012) in the Swiss Alps and with the rapid expansion of drought-sensitive species (e.g. Fagus sylvatica) reconstructed by Tinner and Lotter (2001) at Lake Soppensee on the Swiss Plateau. The tripartite nature of the 8.2 ka event such as reconstructed at Lake Annecy has also been observed in Scandinavia, in the Greenland oxygen-isotope records (Nesje and Dahl, 2001) and it also appears in climate model simulations (Renssen et al., 2001).

Episode 11 (7700–7000 cal. BP) may find equivalents in the climatic reversal observed in Alpine and Central European palaeoclimatic series, e.g. glaciers, treelines, chironomids (Haas et al., 1998; Heiri et al., 2004) as well as in the central Mediterranean (Magny et al., 2011; Siani et al., 2010) and in the North Atlantic and Nordic Seas (Bond et al., 2001; Rasmussen and Thomsen, 2010). It coincided (1) with a period of lower solar activity, (2) with the highest rate of change in annual insolation during the interval 8000–7000 cal. BP (Zhao et al., 2010), and (3) with the final step of the deglaciation marked by final outbursts from proglacial lakes (Magny and Bégeot, 2004).

Episode 10 (6350/6100–5950/5900 cal. BP) and episode 9 (5650–5200 cal. BP) may be paralleled by the Rapid Climate Change (RCC) event defined by Mayewski et al. (2004) at c. 6000–5000 cal. BP. This worldwide climatic oscillation corresponds to the beginning of the Neoglacial (Magny et al., 2006b, 2012c; Steig, 1999).

Episode 7 (4300–3750 cal. BP) is a widespread oscillation including the so-called 4.2 ka event used to mark the mid- to late-Holocene climatic transition (Walker et al., 2012). Recent studies have shown the possible complexity and importance of this event used as a marker of the beginning Neoglacial in the central Mediterranean (Magny et al., 2009c, 2012b; Zanchetta et al., 2012). It corresponds to the RCC event dated to 4200–3800 cal. BP and which was marked by a southward migration of the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) (Mayewski et al., 2004).

Episode 6 (3350–3100 cal. BP) and episode 5 (2750–2300 cal. BP) may be considered as two successive parts of the RCC event dated to 3500–2500 cal. BP by Mayewski et al. (2004). While episode 6 finds many equivalents in palaeoclimatic records in the North-Atlantic area (Magny et al., 2009a), episode 5 corresponds to a widespread climatic oscillation at the Subboreal–Subatlantic transition extensively studied by van Geel and well correlated with a decrease in solar activity (van Geel and Renssen, 1998; van Geel et al., 1996).

Episode 3 (1350–1200 cal. BP) is close to the RCC event defined by Mayewski et al. (2004) at c. 1200–1000 cal. BP. Like the following episode 2 (750–650 cal. BP), it coincides with a cool oscillation in the Alps well documented by a glacier advance(Holzhauser et al., 2005) and temperature records inferred from chironomid, and tree-ring data (Büntgen et al., 2006; Millet et al., 2009). Using various proxy data, Mann et al. (2008) reconstructed a negative temperature anomaly for the period 1550–1250 cal. BP.
Episode 1 (500–300 cal. BP) corresponds to the worldwide climatic oscillation defined as the ‘Little Ice Age’ (Mann et al., 1999, 2008).

Finally, considering a millennial scale, Figure 5 displays a comparison between (1) the lake-level record established at Cerin in the Jura Mountains (Magny et al., 2011), (2) a treeline record reconstructed in the Kauner Valley in the Austrian Alps by Nicolussi et al. (2005) and cited by Bleicher (2013), and (3) the orbitally driven changes in seasonal insolation at 40°N (Berger and Loutre, 1991). Together, the Jurassian and the Austrian records reflect a clear influence of the orbital factor with the lowest water-table and the highest timberline elevation during the Holocene climatic optimum (Renssen et al., 2009). It is noteworthy that the rapid afforestation of the elevated Alpine zone in the Kauner Valley appears to be synchronous with a rapid fall in the Cerin lake level at c. 9000 cal. BP, i.e. just after the disappearance of the Fennoscandian ice sheet (Renssen et al., 2009). This points to the possible role of a residual ice-sheet in northern Europe during the early Holocene (Magny et al., 2011).

Another key feature shown in Figure 5 is the marked increase in the Cerin lake level and decline of the Austrian timberline around 4500–4000 cal. BP, i.e. at the mid- to late-Holocene transition as recently defined by Walker et al. (2012). This climatic oscillation corresponds to episode 7 described above and may be a non-linear response to the gradual decrease of insolation in addition to key seasonal and interhemispherical changes in insolation (Magny et al., 2012b; Zhao et al., 2010). Major palaeohydrological changes have been also described for this time interval in southern Europe (Magny et al., 2009c, 2012b; Zanchetta et al., 2012).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The paper of Bleicher is a stimulating contribution which points to problems linked to the use of CPFs. However, as shown in the present study, the approach developed by Magny (2004) to analyse lake-level data presents only weak similarities (if any) with the CPF technique. Using an approach, in contrast to CPFs, excluding any consideration of variations in the probabilities over the time intervals given by the calibration of 14C dates, a revised pattern of the mid-European high-level events presented in this study fully supports the hypothesis proposed by Magny (2004). In addition, tree-ring dates from lake-shore sites offer another key control for the chronology of this mid-European lake-level record for the time interval from c. 6000 to c. 2500 cal. BP.

The general picture emerging from recent investigations is one of mid-European lake-level fluctuations modulated by a combination of orbital, ice-sheet and possible solar forcing factors. While the orbital factor acts on a millennial scale, centennial-scale climate oscillations may have resulted mainly from variations in solar activity. They also may have indirectly resulted from orbital factors through the impact of meltwater outbursts during the deglaciation, as during the 8.2 ka event, and through a possible non-linear response to threshold values in insolation, such as the event around 4000 cal. BP.

It is clear that further investigations are still needed in order to improve the chronological data set for lake-level fluctuations in west-central Europe, with particular attention to better defining the beginning and end of such events, and finally to reinforce and clarify our understanding of the possible forcing factors and mechanisms behind these Holocene palaeohydrological oscillations.

ack.p: The author would like to thank John Matthews for his invitation to comment on the paper of Bleicher (2013) and to Frank Oldfield for the management of the review process. We are grateful to Ariane Winiger for providing the photograph in Figure 1. We are also indebted to Bas van Geel and Jean Nicolas Haas for comments on a first draft of this paper.
